captions.text:
Good morning John. Today’s Vlogbrothers
is going to be a little bit weird. I am right

now at an antique mall. I found a thing that
I am so amazed by that I just can’t help
but take it apart.

It is now in my home! This thing is at least
25 pounds. It’s made entirely of metal,

and it can do addition and subtraction and
kind of multiplication. Not really.

Obviously, a calculator that can do addition
and subtraction these days is not impressive.

But when it was purchased it probably cost
around as much as a really nice laptop today.

I don’t know how this works, but that's
what I’m going to try and figure out today.

There are a number of amazing things going
on all at once inside of this machine.

First, most simply, let's just put in the
number 99, that’s 99 cents. Both of the

dials will count up to nine. If we add one
to the 99 there, if we add one cent, we’re
gonna get a buck right?

Now, I know how the first column happens.
There is a pin that tells in the machine that

to roll this dial, the first column dial,
one digit. Now that makes sense.

But then it gets carried forward and that
is amazing to me. What? How did this machine,
that is a just a machine, figure that out?

That's what we wanna know, and as far as I
am concerned, there's only one way to find
out. So let’s take it apart.
[music]

Ugh. What is this? Is it a dead animal? Something
crawled in there and died like a thousand

years ago? Oh I have no idea. But I touched
it.

Now this thing comes off and… I got one
of these! I should now be able to lift this

off of the mach-- I can! It’s fuzzy on the
inside. Oh man.

Now this just got way cooler! There’s been
something rolling around in here. I can hear
it. It’s a dime!

1980, so it’s not that old. How does it
stop at the right place? How does it carry

the number? How does the subtract function
work?

Nerdy? Yes. Yes, it's nerdy. It is very nerdy.
Each one of these parts had to be individually

stamped. How do you come off? I hate flat
head screws so much right now.

A lot of these screws are really stuck, which
is not all that surprising. You actually have

to be depressing a button in order to access
this screw; so that’s something. Were those
the only four screws? Yes!

Well something’s happened. Whooooaaaaa.
Okay. This is the back of the number plate.

When you push each of the numbers, it pops
down into one of those nine slots there.

Ah! I got it! I figured it out! When you push
down a number, two things happen. One, that

depression will push down this lever a little
bit, and that actually allows for this thing

up here, the gear that actually turns the
number wheel, to actually start moving.

How much it moves is a question of which key
got pushed down. Whichever button is pushed

will actually block that at a certain point
if nothing stops it, it will go all nine,
and you get nine.

If it stops like half way in the middle then
it stops at five, and it will only count five.

So this oil I have on my fingers right now
was put on here by someone in a factory in

the 1930s. The numbers are somehow responsible
for the digit carrying.

Boy, am I glad I didn’t have to manufacture
these things for a living. I would have not

been good at it. So at zero, this notch holds
this pin, and this pin, when you move it out

of the way, it just automatically advances.
That pin is the secret.

You know, it’s the kind of thing that we
would never make today but it has, in its

functionality, a beauty that I am a big fan
of. It does so many things all at once, and
it is powered only by the crank of the hand.

Thanks to all the people who, uh, you know,
we won't remember the names of who put all

their time and energy into the creation of
these devices. It’s just so very neat. So
very, very neat.
John, I’ll see you on Tuesday.

title: In Which Hank is the Nerdiest Nerd

comments.text:
The R.C. Allen Company also made very fine typewriters, too.  I'm pretty 
sure I still have one in a metal cabinet in  the basement.  It's been there 
for 55 years.  Yes, the old mechanical adding machines were quite a feat of 
engineering; and, they rarely, if ever, broke down.  Yet, the electronic 
calculators--especially the scientific calculators made by Hewlett Packard 
were even more amazing back in the late 70's and early 80's!  A number of 
their models had a built-in printer, too, and an LED display.﻿

comments.author: Maddie Stokes

comments.text:
The IBM Selectric typewriter is also quite a marvel of engineering. It has 
precisely *one* electric part, and that's a motor that runs idly in the 
background.
Everything else in it is mechanical. When you press a key, a clutch is 
released, causing the motor to turn the mechanism inside, moving the 
type-ball to the correct place on the paper, striking it to produce a 
letter.
The thing has a fucking clutch to prevent it from trying to write every 
letter all at once, and in fact, you can't even press more than a single 
key at a time on it.﻿

machines. Seriously. They were heavy, they were bulky, and they had a LOT

part will fail. Usually before the non-moving parts do.﻿

I believe I may have beaten you at being the nerdiest nerd. I may or may 
not have taken apart an ancient telephone, and I mean take apart, like, I 
didn't just remove various covering plates, I completely dismantled this 
phone. I then put it back together with a calculator, and while the 
calculator/phone device was not functional, at the time I completely 
intended to find whatever wiring and parts I needed to make it work. I was 
10, I believe. ﻿

comments.author: TeamGavino

comments.text:
What a fun video, I hope you do more of these! They're the next best thing 
to taking it apart myself. :) I love the elegance of mechanical devices 
like this, and I love that we can figure out what makes them tick 
(sometimes literally) with a few tools, some patience, and an inquisitive 
mind. Don't get me wrong, I love my electronic devices too, but I will 
never understand them- they are basically magic. Mechanical things are 
still mind-blowing, but ultimately relatable.﻿

comments.author: Cheesypotato57

comments.text:
That, BTW, is not an adding machine. An adding machine only has ten keys. 
In the day that was called a calculator and cost a bunch of money. Much 
more than an adding machine, which were cheap. I worked as a pay roll clerk 
many years ago when those machines were what we used.  They can do some 
things an adding machine can't do but you have to know the steps for doing 
things other than simple addition. i hated that machine. Now it's an 
interesting conversation piece rather than a torture device for junior 
clerks with large complex payrolls to deal with. :)﻿

 Nothing better than old oil all over your hands.  ﻿
